element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

resource.name: dateTime
resource.description: Base StructureDefinition for dateTime Type: A date, date-time or partial date (e.g. just year or year + month).  If hours and minutes are specified, a time zone SHALL be populated. The format is a union of the schema types gYear, gYearMonth, date and dateTime. Seconds must be provided due to schema type constraints but may be zero-filled and may be ignored.                 Dates SHALL be valid dates.

element.definition: A date, date-time or partial date (e.g. just year or year + month).  If hours and minutes are specified, a time zone SHALL be populated. The format is a union of the schema types gYear, gYearMonth, date and dateTime. Seconds must be provided due to schema type constraints but may be zero-filled and may be ignored.                 Dates SHALL be valid dates.

resource.name: Address
resource.description: Base StructureDefinition for Address Type: An address expressed using postal conventions (as opposed to GPS or other location definition formats).  This data type may be used to convey addresses for use in delivering mail as well as for visiting locations which might not be valid for mail delivery.  There are a variety of postal address formats defined around the world.
resource.purpose: Need to be able to record postal addresses, along with notes about their use.

element.short: An address expressed using postal conventions (as opposed to GPS or other location definition formats)
element.definition: An address expressed using postal conventions (as opposed to GPS or other location definition formats).  This data type may be used to convey addresses for use in delivering mail as well as for visiting locations which might not be valid for mail delivery.  There are a variety of postal address formats defined around the world.
element.comment: Note: address is intended to describe postal addresses for administrative purposes, not to describe absolute geographical coordinates.  Postal addresses are often used as proxies for physical locations (also see the [Location](location.html#) resource).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: home | work | temp | old | billing - purpose of this address
element.definition: The purpose of this address.
element.comment: Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc.for a current/permanent one

binding.description: The use of an address.

element.definition: Distinguishes between physical addresses (those you can visit) and mailing addresses (e.g. PO Boxes and care-of addresses). Most addresses are both.
element.comment: The definition of Address states that "address is intended to describe postal addresses, not physical locations". However, many applications track whether an address has a dual purpose of being a location that can be visited as well as being a valid delivery destination, and Postal addresses are often used as proxies for physical locations (also see the [Location](location.html#) resource).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of an address (physical / postal).

element.definition: Specifies the entire address as it should be displayed e.g. on a postal label. This may be provided instead of or as well as the specific parts.
element.comment: Can provide both a text representation and parts. Applications updating an address SHALL ensure that  when both text and parts are present,  no content is included in the text that isn't found in a part.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

element.short: Street name, number, direction & P.O. Box etc.
element.definition: This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction,  P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.
element.orderMeaning: The order in which lines should appear in an address label

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)

element.definition: The name of the city, town, suburb, village or other community or delivery center.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The name of the administrative area (county).
element.comment: District is sometimes known as county, but in some regions 'county' is used in place of city (municipality), so county name should be conveyed in city instead.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (e.g. US 2 letter state codes).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Country (e.g. can be ISO 3166 2 or 3 letter code)
element.definition: Country - a nation as commonly understood or generally accepted.
element.comment: ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a human readable country name.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Time period when address was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when address was/is in use.
element.requirements: Allows addresses to be placed in historical context.

There are a variety of postal address formats defined around the world.

text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
AgeÎ£ITUQuantityA duration of time during which an organism (or a process) has existed
Common UCUM Codes for Age (Extensible but limited to AllUCUMExpressionForTime)
+ Rule: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of time. If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM. If value is present, it SHALL be positive.
Elements defined in Ancestors: id, extension, value, comparator, unit, system, code

Documentation for this format

resource.name: Age
resource.description: Base StructureDefinition for Age Type: A duration of time during which an organism (or a process) has existed.

element.short: A duration of time during which an organism (or a process) has existed
element.definition: A duration of time during which an organism (or a process) has existed.
element.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.

constraint.human: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of time.  If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.  If value is present, it SHALL be positive.
constraint.expression: (code.exists() or value.empty()) and (system.empty() or system = %ucum) and (value.empty() or value.hasValue().not() or value > 0)
constraint.xpath: (f:code or not(f:value)) and (not(exists(f:system)) or f:system/@value='http://unitsofmeasure.org') and (not(f:value/@value) or f:value/@value >=0)

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If a code for the unit is present, the system SHALL also be present

binding.description: Appropriate units for Age.

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values

Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
element.comment: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).
element.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

element.definition: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues; e.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
element.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

binding.description: How the Quantity should be understood and represented.

element.definition: A human-readable form of the unit.
element.requirements: There are many representations for units of measure and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. I.e. mcg for micrograms.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: System that defines coded unit form
element.definition: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit.
element.requirements: Need to know the system that defines the coded form of the unit.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A computer processable form of the unit in some unit representation system.
element.comment: The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.  The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system.
element.requirements: Need a computable form of the unit that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A duration of time during which an organism (or a process) has existed
element.definition: A duration of time during which an organism (or a process) has existed.

constraint.human: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of time.  If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.  If value is present, it SHALL be positive.
constraint.expression: (code.exists() or value.empty()) and (system.empty() or system = %ucum) and (value.empty() or value.hasValue().not() or value > 0)
constraint.xpath: (f:code or not(f:value)) and (not(exists(f:system)) or f:system/@value='http://unitsofmeasure.org') and (not(f:value/@value) or f:value/@value >=0)

binding.description: Appropriate units for Age.

resource.name: Attachment
resource.description: Base StructureDefinition for Attachment Type: For referring to data content defined in other formats.
resource.purpose: Many models need to include data defined in other specifications that is complex and opaque to the healthcare model. This includes documents, media recordings, structured data, etc.

element.short: Content in a format defined elsewhere
element.definition: For referring to data content defined in other formats.
element.comment: When providing a summary view (for example with Observation.value[x]) Attachment should be represented with a brief display text such as "Signed Procedure Consent".

constraint.human: If the Attachment has data, it SHALL have a contentType
All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Mime type of the content, with charset etc.
element.definition: Identifies the type of the data in the attachment and allows a method to be chosen to interpret or render the data. Includes mime type parameters such as charset where appropriate.
element.requirements: Processors of the data need to be able to know how to interpret the data.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

mapping.map: ED.2+ED.3/RP.2+RP.3. Note conversion may be needed if old style values are being used

element.definition: The human language of the content. The value can be any valid value according to BCP 47.
element.requirements: Users need to be able to choose between the languages in a set of attachments.

binding.description: A human language.

element.definition: The actual data of the attachment - a sequence of bytes, base64 encoded.
element.comment: The base64-encoded data SHALL be expressed in the same character set as the base resource XML or JSON.
element.requirements: The data needs to able to be transmitted inline.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Uri where the data can be found
element.definition: A location where the data can be accessed.
element.comment: If both data and url are provided, the url SHALL point to the same content as the data contains. Urls may be relative references or may reference transient locations such as a wrapping envelope using cid: though this has ramifications for using signatures. Relative URLs are interpreted relative to the service url, like a resource reference, rather than relative to the resource itself. If a URL is provided, it SHALL resolve to actual data.
element.requirements: The data needs to be transmitted by reference.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: RP.1+RP.2 - if they refer to a URL (see v2.6)

element.short: Number of bytes of content (if url provided)
element.definition: The number of bytes of data that make up this attachment (before base64 encoding, if that is done).
element.comment: The number of bytes is redundant if the data is provided as a base64binary, but is useful if the data is provided as a url reference.
element.requirements: Representing the size allows applications to determine whether they should fetch the content automatically in advance, or refuse to fetch it at all.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The calculated hash of the data using SHA-1. Represented using base64.
element.comment: The hash is calculated on the data prior to base64 encoding, if the data is based64 encoded. The hash is not intended to support digital signatures. Where protection against malicious threats a digital signature should be considered, see [Provenance.signature](provenance-definitions.html#Provenance.signature) for mechanism to protect a resource with a digital signature.
element.requirements: Included so that applications can verify that the contents of a location have not changed due to technical failures (e.g., storage rot, transport glitch, incorrect version).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.requirements: Applications need a label to display to a human user in place of the actual data if the data cannot be rendered or perceived by the viewer.

resource.purpose: This is a common pattern in healthcare - a concept that may be defined by one or more codes from formal definitions including LOINC and SNOMED CT, and/or defined by the provision of text that captures a human sense of the concept.

element.short: Concept - reference to a terminology or just  text
element.definition: A concept that may be defined by a formal reference to a terminology or ontology or may be provided by text.
element.comment: Not all terminology uses fit this general pattern. In some cases, models should not use CodeableConcept and use Coding directly and provide their own structure for managing text, codings, translations and the relationship between elements and pre- and post-coordination.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comment: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL NOT be used to infer meaning. Generally, at most only one of the coding values will be labeled as UserSelected = true.
element.requirements: Allows for alternative encodings within a code system, and translations to other code systems.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comment: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

resource.name: Coding
resource.description: Base StructureDefinition for Coding Type: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
resource.purpose: References to codes are very common in healthcare models.

element.short: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comment: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: CE/CNE/CWE subset one of the sets of component 1-3 or 4-6

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should reference to some definition that establishes the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured, and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - e.g. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
element.comment: Additional text data such as phone extension numbers, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value.
element.requirements: Need to support legacy numbers that are not in a tightly controlled format.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Identifies the purpose for the contact point.
element.comment: Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Need to track the way a person uses this contact, so a user can choose which is appropriate for their purpose.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old contact etc.for a current/permanent one

binding.description: Use of contact point.

element.definition: Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. ContactPoints with lower rank values are more preferred than those with higher rank values.
element.comment: Note that rank does not necessarily follow the order in which the contacts are represented in the instance.

text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
CountÎ£ITUQuantityA measured or measurable amount
+ Rule: There SHALL be a code with a value of "1" if there is a value. If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM. If present, the value SHALL be a whole number.
Elements defined in Ancestors: id, extension, value, comparator, unit, system, code

Documentation for this format

resource.name: Count
resource.description: Base StructureDefinition for Count Type: A measured amount (or an amount that can potentially be measured). Note that measured amounts include amounts that are not precisely quantified, including amounts involving arbitrary units and floating currencies.
resource.purpose: Need to able to capture all sorts of measured values, even if the measured value are not precisely quantified. Values include exact measures such as 3.51g, customary units such as 3 tablets, and currencies such as $100.32USD.

element.definition: A measured amount (or an amount that can potentially be measured). Note that measured amounts include amounts that are not precisely quantified, including amounts involving arbitrary units and floating currencies.
element.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.

constraint.human: There SHALL be a code with a value of "1" if there is a value. If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.  If present, the value SHALL be a whole number.
constraint.expression: (code.exists() or value.empty()) and (system.empty() or system = %ucum) and (code.empty() or code = '1') and (value.empty() or value.hasValue().not() or value.toString().contains('.').not())
constraint.xpath: (f:code or not(f:value)) and (not(exists(f:system)) or (f:system/@value='http://unitsofmeasure.org' and f:code/@value='1')) and not(contains(f:value/@value, '.'))

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If a code for the unit is present, the system SHALL also be present

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
element.comment: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).
element.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

element.definition: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues; e.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
element.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

binding.description: How the Quantity should be understood and represented.

element.definition: A human-readable form of the unit.
element.requirements: There are many representations for units of measure and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. I.e. mcg for micrograms.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: System that defines coded unit form
element.definition: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit.
element.requirements: Need to know the system that defines the coded form of the unit.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A computer processable form of the unit in some unit representation system.
element.comment: The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.  The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system.
element.requirements: Need a computable form of the unit that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A measured amount (or an amount that can potentially be measured). Note that measured amounts include amounts that are not precisely quantified, including amounts involving arbitrary units and floating currencies.
element.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.

constraint.human: There SHALL be a code with a value of "1" if there is a value. If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.  If present, the value SHALL be a whole number.
constraint.expression: (code.exists() or value.empty()) and (system.empty() or system = %ucum) and (code.empty() or code = '1') and (value.empty() or value.hasValue().not() or value.toString().contains('.').not())
constraint.xpath: (f:code or not(f:value)) and (not(exists(f:system)) or (f:system/@value='http://unitsofmeasure.org' and f:code/@value='1')) and not(contains(f:value/@value, '.'))

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values

text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
DistanceÎ£ITUQuantityA length - a value with a unit that is a physical distance
Common UCUM Codes for Distance (Extensible but limited to AllUCUMExpressionForDistance)
+ Rule: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of length. If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.
Elements defined in Ancestors: id, extension, value, comparator, unit, system, code

Documentation for this format

resource.name: Distance
resource.description: Base StructureDefinition for Distance Type: A length - a value with a unit that is a physical distance.

element.short: A length - a value with a unit that is a physical distance
element.definition: A length - a value with a unit that is a physical distance.
element.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.

constraint.human: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of length.  If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.
All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If a code for the unit is present, the system SHALL also be present

binding.description: Appropriate units for Distance.

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
element.comment: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).
element.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

element.definition: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues; e.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
element.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

binding.description: How the Quantity should be understood and represented.

element.definition: A human-readable form of the unit.
element.requirements: There are many representations for units of measure and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. I.e. mcg for micrograms.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: System that defines coded unit form
element.definition: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit.
element.requirements: Need to know the system that defines the coded form of the unit.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A computer processable form of the unit in some unit representation system.
element.comment: The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.  The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system.
element.requirements: Need a computable form of the unit that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A length - a value with a unit that is a physical distance
element.definition: A length - a value with a unit that is a physical distance.

constraint.human: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of length.  If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.

binding.description: Appropriate units for Distance.

text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
DosageÎ£TUBackBoneElementHow the medication is/was taken or should be taken
Elements defined in Ancestors: id, extension, modifierExtension
sequenceÎ£0..1integerThe order of the dosage instructions
textÎ£0..1stringFree text dosage instructions e.g. SIG
additionalInstructionÎ£0..*CodeableConceptSupplemental instruction or warnings to the patient - e.g. "with meals", "may cause drowsiness"
SNOMED CT Additional Dosage Instructions (Example)
patientInstructionÎ£0..1stringPatient or consumer oriented instructions
timingÎ£0..1TimingWhen medication should be administered
asNeeded[x]Î£0..1Take "as needed" (for x)
SNOMED CT Medication As Needed Reason Codes (Example)
asNeededBooleanboolean
asNeededCodeableConceptCodeableConcept
siteÎ£0..1CodeableConceptBody site to administer to
SNOMED CT Anatomical Structure for Administration Site Codes (Example)
routeÎ£0..1CodeableConceptHow drug should enter body
SNOMED CT Route Codes (Example)
methodÎ£0..1CodeableConceptTechnique for administering medication
SNOMED CT Administration Method Codes (Example)
doseAndRateÎ£0..*ElementAmount of medication administered
typeÎ£0..1CodeableConceptThe kind of dose or rate specified
DoseAndRateType (Example)
dose[x]Î£0..1Amount of medication per dose
doseRangeRange
doseQuantitySimpleQuantity
rate[x]Î£0..1Amount of medication per unit of time
rateRatioRatio
rateRangeRange
rateQuantitySimpleQuantity
maxDosePerPeriodÎ£0..1RatioUpper limit on medication per unit of time
maxDosePerAdministrationÎ£0..1SimpleQuantityUpper limit on medication per administration
maxDosePerLifetimeÎ£0..1SimpleQuantityUpper limit on medication per lifetime of the patient

Documentation for this format

resource.name: Dosage
resource.description: Base StructureDefinition for Dosage Type: Indicates how the medication is/was taken or should be taken by the patient.

element.short: How the medication is/was taken or should be taken
element.definition: Indicates how the medication is/was taken or should be taken by the patient.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: The order of the dosage instructions
element.definition: Indicates the order in which the dosage instructions should be applied or interpreted.
element.requirements: If the sequence number of multiple Dosages is the same, then it is implied that the instructions are to be treated as concurrent.  If the sequence number is different, then the Dosages are intended to be sequential.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Free text dosage instructions e.g. SIG
element.definition: Free text dosage instructions e.g. SIG.
element.requirements: Free text dosage instructions can be used for cases where the instructions are too complex to code.  The content of this attribute does not include the name or description of the medication. When coded instructions are present, the free text instructions may still be present for display to humans taking or administering the medication. It is expected that the text instructions will always be populated.  If the dosage.timing attribute is also populated, then the dosage.text should reflect the same information as the timing.  Additional information about administration or preparation of the medication should be included as text.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Supplemental instruction or warnings to the patient - e.g. "with meals", "may cause drowsiness"
element.definition: Supplemental instructions to the patient on how to take the medication  (e.g. "with meals" or"take half to one hour before food") or warnings for the patient about the medication (e.g. "may cause drowsiness" or "avoid exposure of skin to direct sunlight or sunlamps").
element.comment: Information about administration or preparation of the medication (e.g. "infuse as rapidly as possibly via intraperitoneal port" or "immediately following drug x") should be populated in dosage.text.
element.requirements: Additional instruction is intended to be coded, but where no code exists, the element could include text.  For example, "Swallow with plenty of water" which might or might not be coded.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded concept identifying additional instructions such as "take with water" or "avoid operating heavy machinery".

element.definition: Instructions in terms that are understood by the patient or consumer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: When medication should be administered.
element.comment: This attribute might not always be populated while the Dosage.text is expected to be populated.  If both are populated, then the Dosage.text should reflect the content of the Dosage.timing.
element.requirements: The timing schedule for giving the medication to the patient. This  data type allows many different expressions. For example: "Every 8 hours"; "Three times a day"; "1/2 an hour before breakfast for 10 days from 23-Dec 2011:"; "15 Oct 2013, 17 Oct 2013 and 1 Nov 2013".  Sometimes, a rate can imply duration when expressed as total volume / duration (e.g.  500mL/2 hours implies a duration of 2 hours).  However, when rate doesn't imply duration (e.g. 250mL/hour), then the timing.repeat.duration is needed to convey the infuse over time period.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Indicates whether the Medication is only taken when needed within a specific dosing schedule (Boolean option), or it indicates the precondition for taking the Medication (CodeableConcept).
element.comment: Can express "as needed" without a reason by setting the Boolean = True.  In this case the CodeableConcept is not populated.  Or you can express "as needed" with a reason by including the CodeableConcept.  In this case the Boolean is assumed to be True.  If you set the Boolean to False, then the dose is given according to the schedule and is not "prn" or "as needed".

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded concept identifying the precondition that should be met or evaluated prior to consuming or administering a medication dose.  For example "pain", "30 minutes prior to sexual intercourse", "on flare-up" etc.

mapping.map: .outboundRelationship[typeCode=PRCN].target[classCode=OBS, moodCode=EVN, code="as needed"].value=boolean or codable concept

element.definition: Body site to administer to.
element.comment: If the use case requires attributes from the BodySite resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension [bodySite](extension-bodysite.html).  May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both.
element.requirements: A coded specification of the anatomic site where the medication first enters the body.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded concept describing the site location the medicine enters into or onto the body.

element.definition: How drug should enter body.
element.requirements: A code specifying the route or physiological path of administration of a therapeutic agent into or onto a patient's body.

element.definition: Technique for administering medication.
element.comment: Terminologies used often pre-coordinate this term with the route and or form of administration.
element.requirements: A coded value indicating the method by which the medication is introduced into or onto the body. Most commonly used for injections.  For examples, Slow Push; Deep IV.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded concept describing the technique by which the medicine is administered.

element.definition: The amount of medication administered.

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: The kind of dose or rate specified
element.definition: The kind of dose or rate specified, for example, ordered or calculated.
element.requirements: If the type is not populated, assume to be "ordered".

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The kind of dose or rate specified.

element.definition: Amount of medication per dose.
element.comment: Note that this specifies the quantity of the specified medication, not the quantity for each active ingredient(s). Each ingredient amount can be communicated in the Medication resource. For example, if one wants to communicate that a tablet was 375 mg, where the dose was one tablet, you can use the Medication resource to document that the tablet was comprised of 375 mg of drug XYZ. Alternatively if the dose was 375 mg, then you may only need to use the Medication resource to indicate this was a tablet. If the example were an IV such as dopamine and you wanted to communicate that 400mg of dopamine was mixed in 500 ml of some IV solution, then this would all be communicated in the Medication resource. If the administration is not intended to be instantaneous (rate is present or timing has a duration), this can be specified to convey the total amount to be administered over the period of time as indicated by the schedule e.g. 500 ml in dose, with timing used to convey that this should be done over 4 hours.
element.requirements: The amount of therapeutic or other substance given at one administration event.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Amount of medication per unit of time
element.definition: Amount of medication per unit of time.
element.comment: It is possible to supply both a rate and a doseQuantity to provide full details about how the medication is to be administered and supplied. If the rate is intended to change over time, depending on local rules/regulations, each change should be captured as a new version of the MedicationRequest with an updated rate, or captured with a new MedicationRequest with the new rate.It is possible to specify a rate over time (for example, 100 ml/hour) using either the rateRatio and rateQuantity.  The rateQuantity approach requires systems to have the capability to parse UCUM grammer where ml/hour is included rather than a specific ratio where the time is specified as the denominator.  Where a rate such as 500ml over 2 hours is specified, the use of rateRatio may be more semantically correct than specifying using a rateQuantity of 250 mg/hour.
element.requirements: Identifies the speed with which the medication was or will be introduced into the patient. Typically the rate for an infusion e.g. 100 ml per 1 hour or 100 ml/hr.  May also be expressed as a rate per unit of time e.g. 500 ml per 2 hours.   Other examples: 200 mcg/min or 200 mcg/1 minute; 1 liter/8 hours.  Sometimes, a rate can imply duration when expressed as total volume / duration (e.g.  500mL/2 hours implies a duration of 2 hours).  However, when rate doesn't imply duration (e.g. 250mL/hour), then the timing.repeat.duration is needed to convey the infuse over time period.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Upper limit on medication per unit of time
element.definition: Upper limit on medication per unit of time.
element.comment: This is intended for use as an adjunct to the dosage when there is an upper cap.  For example "2 tablets every 4 hours to a maximum of 8/day".
element.requirements: The maximum total quantity of a therapeutic substance that may be administered to a subject over the period of time.  For example, 1000mg in 24 hours.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Upper limit on medication per administration
element.definition: Upper limit on medication per administration.
element.comment: This is intended for use as an adjunct to the dosage when there is an upper cap.  For example, a body surface area related dose with a maximum amount, such as 1.5 mg/m2 (maximum 2 mg) IV over 5 â 10 minutes would have doseQuantity of 1.5 mg/m2 and maxDosePerAdministration of 2 mg.
element.requirements: The maximum total quantity of a therapeutic substance that may be administered to a subject per administration.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Upper limit on medication per lifetime of the patient
element.definition: Upper limit on medication per lifetime of the patient.
element.requirements: The maximum total quantity of a therapeutic substance that may be administered per lifetime of the subject.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: How the medication is/was taken or should be taken
element.definition: Indicates how the medication is/was taken or should be taken by the patient.

element.short: The order of the dosage instructions
element.definition: Indicates the order in which the dosage instructions should be applied or interpreted.
element.requirements: If the sequence number of multiple Dosages is the same, then it is implied that the instructions are to be treated as concurrent.  If the sequence number is different, then the Dosages are intended to be sequential.

element.short: Free text dosage instructions e.g. SIG
element.definition: Free text dosage instructions e.g. SIG.
element.requirements: Free text dosage instructions can be used for cases where the instructions are too complex to code.  The content of this attribute does not include the name or description of the medication. When coded instructions are present, the free text instructions may still be present for display to humans taking or administering the medication. It is expected that the text instructions will always be populated.  If the dosage.timing attribute is also populated, then the dosage.text should reflect the same information as the timing.  Additional information about administration or preparation of the medication should be included as text.

element.short: Supplemental instruction or warnings to the patient - e.g. "with meals", "may cause drowsiness"
element.definition: Supplemental instructions to the patient on how to take the medication  (e.g. "with meals" or"take half to one hour before food") or warnings for the patient about the medication (e.g. "may cause drowsiness" or "avoid exposure of skin to direct sunlight or sunlamps").
element.comment: Information about administration or preparation of the medication (e.g. "infuse as rapidly as possibly via intraperitoneal port" or "immediately following drug x") should be populated in dosage.text.
element.requirements: Additional instruction is intended to be coded, but where no code exists, the element could include text.  For example, "Swallow with plenty of water" which might or might not be coded.

binding.description: A coded concept identifying additional instructions such as "take with water" or "avoid operating heavy machinery".

element.definition: Instructions in terms that are understood by the patient or consumer.
When medication should be administered.
element.comment: This attribute might not always be populated while the Dosage.text is expected to be populated.  If both are populated, then the Dosage.text should reflect the content of the Dosage.timing.
element.requirements: The timing schedule for giving the medication to the patient. This  data type allows many different expressions. For example: "Every 8 hours"; "Three times a day"; "1/2 an hour before breakfast for 10 days from 23-Dec 2011:"; "15 Oct 2013, 17 Oct 2013 and 1 Nov 2013".  Sometimes, a rate can imply duration when expressed as total volume / duration (e.g.  500mL/2 hours implies a duration of 2 hours).  However, when rate doesn't imply duration (e.g. 250mL/hour), then the timing.repeat.duration is needed to convey the infuse over time period.

element.definition: Indicates whether the Medication is only taken when needed within a specific dosing schedule (Boolean option), or it indicates the precondition for taking the Medication (CodeableConcept).
element.comment: Can express "as needed" without a reason by setting the Boolean = True.  In this case the CodeableConcept is not populated.  Or you can express "as needed" with a reason by including the CodeableConcept.  In this case the Boolean is assumed to be True.  If you set the Boolean to False, then the dose is given according to the schedule and is not "prn" or "as needed".

binding.description: A coded concept identifying the precondition that should be met or evaluated prior to consuming or administering a medication dose.  For example "pain", "30 minutes prior to sexual intercourse", "on flare-up" etc.

mapping.map: .outboundRelationship[typeCode=PRCN].target[classCode=OBS, moodCode=EVN, code="as needed"].value=boolean or codable concept

element.definition: Body site to administer to.
element.comment: If the use case requires attributes from the BodySite resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension [bodySite](extension-bodysite.html).  May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both.
element.requirements: A coded specification of the anatomic site where the medication first enters the body.

binding.description: A coded concept describing the site location the medicine enters into or onto the body.

element.definition: How drug should enter body.

text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
DurationÎ£INQuantityA length of time
Common UCUM Codes for Duration (Extensible but limited to AllUCUMExpressionForTime)
+ Rule: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of time. If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.
Elements defined in Ancestors: id, extension, value, comparator, unit, system, code

Documentation for this format

resource.name: Duration
resource.description: Base StructureDefinition for Duration Type: A length of time.

element.definition: A length of time.
element.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.

constraint.human: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of time.  If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.
All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If a code for the unit is present, the system SHALL also be present

binding.description: Appropriate units for Duration.

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values
PQ, IVL<PQ> depending on the values

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
element.comment: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).
element.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

element.definition: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues; e.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
element.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

binding.description: How the Quantity should be understood and represented.

element.definition: A human-readable form of the unit.
element.requirements: There are many representations for units of measure and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. I.e. mcg for micrograms.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: System that defines coded unit form
element.definition: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit.
element.requirements: Need to know the system that defines the coded form of the unit.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A computer processable form of the unit in some unit representation system.
element.comment: The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.  The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system.
element.requirements: Need a computable form of the unit that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A length of time.

constraint.human: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of time.  If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.

binding.description: Appropriate units for Duration.

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ> depending on the values

text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
ElementDefinitionÎ£INBackBoneElementDefinition of an element in a resource or extension
+ Rule: Min <= Max
+ Rule: if the element definition has a contentReference, it cannot have type, defaultValue, fixed, pattern, example, minValue, maxValue, maxLength, or binding
+ Rule: Fixed value may only be specified if there is one type
+ Rule: Pattern may only be specified if there is one type
+ Rule: Pattern and fixed are mutually exclusive
+ Rule: Binding can only be present for coded elements, string, and uri
+ Rule: Types must be unique by code
+ Rule: Constraints must be unique by key
+ Rule: default value and meaningWhenMissing are mutually exclusive
+ Rule: sliceName must be composed of proper tokens separated by "/"
+ Rule: Must have a modifier reason if isModifier = true
+ Rule: Element names cannot include some special characters
+ Warning: Element names should be simple alphanumerics with a max of 64 characters, or code generation tools may be broken
+ Rule: sliceIsConstraining can only appear if slicename is present
Elements defined in Ancestors: id, extension, modifierExtension
pathÎ£1..1stringPath of the element in the hierarchy of elements
representationÎ£0..*codexmlAttr | xmlText | typeAttr | cdaText | xhtml
PropertyRepresentation (Required)
sliceNameÎ£0..1stringName for this particular element (in a set of slices)
sliceIsConstrainingÎ£TU0..1booleanIf this slice definition constrains an inherited slice definition (or not)
labelÎ£0..1stringName for element to display with or prompt for element
codeÎ£0..*CodingCorresponding codes in terminologies
LOINC Codes (Example)
slicingÎ£I0..1ElementThis element is sliced - slices follow
+ Rule: If there are no discriminators, there must be a definition
discriminatorÎ£0..*ElementElement values that are used to distinguish the slices
typeÎ£1..1codevalue | exists | pattern | type | profile
DiscriminatorType (Required)
pathÎ£1..1stringPath to element value
descriptionÎ£I0..1stringText description of how slicing works (or not)
orderedÎ£0..1booleanIf elements must be in same order as slices
rulesÎ£1..1codeclosed | open | openAtEnd
SlicingRules (Required)
shortÎ£0..1stringConcise definition for space-constrained presentation
definitionÎ£0..1markdownFull formal definition as narrative text
commentÎ£0..1markdownComments about the use of this element
requirementsÎ£0..1markdownWhy this resource has been created
aliasÎ£0..*stringOther names
minÎ£I0..1unsignedIntMinimum Cardinality
maxÎ£I0..1stringMaximum Cardinality (a number or *)
+ Rule: Max SHALL be a number or "*"
baseÎ£0..1ElementBase definition information for tools
pathÎ£1..1stringPath that identifies the base element
minÎ£1..1unsignedIntMin cardinality of the base element
maxÎ£1..1stringMax cardinality of the base element
contentReferenceÎ£I0..1uriReference to definition of content for the element
typeÎ£I0..*ElementData type and Profile for this element
+ Rule: Aggregation may only be specified if one of the allowed types for the element is a reference
+ Rule: targetProfile is only allowed if the type is Reference or canonical
codeÎ£1..1uriData type or Resource (reference to definition)
FHIRDefinedType (Extensible)
profileÎ£0..*canonical(StructureDefinition | ImplementationGuide)Profiles (StructureDefinition or IG) - one must apply
targetProfileÎ£0..*canonical(StructureDefinition | ImplementationGuide)Profile (StructureDefinition or IG) on the Reference/canonical target - one must apply
aggregationÎ£I0..*codecontained | referenced | bundled - how aggregated
AggregationMode (Required)
versioningÎ£0..1codeeither | independent | specific
ReferenceVersionRules (Required)
defaultValue[x]Î£I0..1*Specified value if missing from instance
meaningWhenMissingÎ£I0..1markdownImplicit meaning when this element is missing
orderMeaningÎ£0..1stringWhat the order of the elements means
fixed[x]Î£I0..1*Value must be exactly this
pattern[x]Î£I0..1*Value must have at least these property values
exampleÎ£0..*ElementExample value (as defined for type)
labelÎ£1..1stringDescribes the purpose of this example
value[x]Î£1..1*Value of Example (one of allowed types)
minValue[x]Î£0..1Minimum Allowed Value (for some types)
minValueDatedate
minValueDateTimedateTime
minValueInstantinstant
minValueTimetime
minValueDecimaldecimal
minValueIntegerinteger
minValuePositiveIntpositiveInt
minValueUnsignedIntunsignedInt
minValueQuantityQuantity
maxValue[x]Î£0..1Maximum Allowed Value (for some types)
maxValueDatedate
maxValueDateTimedateTime
maxValueInstantinstant
maxValueTimetime
maxValueDecimaldecimal
maxValueIntegerinteger
maxValuePositiveIntpositiveInt
maxValueUnsignedIntunsignedInt
maxValueQuantityQuantity
maxLengthÎ£0..1integerMax length for strings
conditionÎ£0..*idReference to invariant about presence
constraintÎ£I0..*ElementCondition that must evaluate to true
+ Warning: Constraints should have an expression or else validators will not be able to enforce them
keyÎ£I1..1idTarget of 'condition' reference above
requirementsÎ£0..1stringWhy this constraint is necessary or appropriate
severityÎ£1..1codeerror | warning
ConstraintSeverity (Required)
humanÎ£1..1stringHuman description of constraint
expressionÎ£0..1stringFHIRPath expression of constraint
xpathÎ£TU0..1stringXPath expression of constraint
sourceÎ£0..1canonical(StructureDefinition)Reference to original source of constraint
mustSupportÎ£0..1booleanIf the element must be supported
isModifierÎ£0..1booleanIf this modifies the meaning of other elements
isModifierReasonÎ£0..1stringReason that this element is marked as a modifier
isSummaryÎ£0..1booleanInclude when _summary = true?
bindingÎ£I0..1ElementValueSet details if this is coded
+ Rule: ValueSet SHALL start with http:// or https:// or urn:
strengthÎ£1..1coderequired | extensible | preferred | example
BindingStrength (Required)
descriptionÎ£0..1stringHuman explanation of the value set
valueSetÎ£I0..1canonical(ValueSet)Source of value set
mappingÎ£0..*ElementMap element to another set of definitions
identityÎ£1..1idReference to mapping declaration
languageÎ£0..1codeComputable language of mapping
MimeType (Required)
mapÎ£1..1stringDetails of the mapping
commentÎ£0..1stringComments about the mapping or its use

Documentation for this format

element.definition: Captures constraints on each element within the resource, profile, or extension.

constraint.human: Min <= Max
constraint.expression: min.empty() or max.empty() or (max = '*') or iif(max != '*', min <= max.toInteger())
constraint.xpath: not(exists(f:min)) or not(exists(f:max)) or (not(f:max/@value) and not(f:min/@value)) or (f:max/@value = '*') or (number(f:max/@value) >= f:min/@value)

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.definition: The path identifies the element and is expressed as a "."-separated list of ancestor elements, beginning with the name of the resource or extension.

This element is used quite commonly in Logical models when the logical models represent a specific serialization format (e.g. CDA, v2 etc.).

element.comment: The name SHALL be unique within the structure within the context of the constrained resource element.  (Though to avoid confusion, uniqueness across all elements is recommended.).
element.requirements: May also be used for code generation purposes.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: If this slice definition constrains an inherited slice definition (or not)
element.definition: If true, indicates that this slice definition is constraining a slice definition with the same name in an inherited profile. If false, the slice is not overriding any slice in an inherited profile. If missing, the slice might or might not be overriding a slice in an inherited profile, depending on the sliceName.
element.comment: If set to true, an ancestor profile SHALL have a slicing definition with this name.  If set to false, no ancestor profile is permitted to have a slicing definition with this name.
element.requirements: Allows detection of a situation where an ancestor profile adds or removes slicing with the same name where that might impact the child profile.

Where multiple codes exist in a terminology that could correspond to the data element, the most granular code(s) should be selected, so long as they are not more restrictive than the data element itself. The mappings may be used to provide more or less granular or structured equivalences in the code system.

element.short: This element is sliced - slices follow
element.definition: Indicates that the element is sliced into a set of alternative definitions (i.e. in a structure definition, there are multiple different constraints on a single element in the base resource). Slicing can be used in any resource that has cardinality ..* on the base resource, or any resource with a choice of types. The set of slices is any elements that come after this in the element sequence that have the same path, until a shorter path occurs (the shorter path terminates the set).
element.comment: The first element in the sequence, the one that carries the slicing, is the definition that applies to all the slices. This is based on the unconstrained element, but can apply any constraints as appropriate. This may include the common constraints on the children of the element.

The URL can be a local reference - to a contained StructureDefinition, or a reference to another StructureDefinition or Implementation Guide by a canonical URL. When an implementation guide is specified, the type SHALL conform to at least one profile defined in the implementation guide.

element.short: Specified value if missing from instance
element.definition: The value that should be used if there is no value stated in the instance (e.g. 'if not otherwise specified, the abstract is false').
element.comment:
Specifying a default value means that the property can never been unknown - it must always have a value. Further, the default value can never be changed, or changed in constraints on content models. Defining default values creates many difficulties in implementation (e.g. when is a value missing?). For these reasons, default values are (and should be) used extremely sparingly. 

No default values are ever defined in the FHIR specification, nor can they be defined in constraints ("profiles") on data types or resources. This element only exists so that default values may be defined in logical models.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Implicit meaning when this element is missing
element.definition: The Implicit meaning that is to be understood when this element is missing (e.g. 'when this element is missing, the period is ongoing').
element.comment: Implicit meanings for missing values can only be specified on a resource, data type, or extension definition, and never in a profile that applies to one of these. An implicit meaning for a missing value can never be changed, and specifying one has the consequence that constraining its use in profiles eliminates use cases as possibilities, not merely moving them out of scope.
